Richard Gong wrote:
> Hey,
>
> Why it is that when NEAT (or maybe just sharpNEAT, what I'm looking at) runs networks, the input neurons' signals don't get changed even though there are connections to them? Unlike the other neurons, the input neurons are constantly firing, their signals don't reset to 0 after they fire.
>   

There shouldn't be any connections going *to* input nodes, only from 
them. If you are seeing such connections then that is a bug. The input 
neurons in SharpNEAT are nothing more than memory locations with a value 
in them, whatever value you put in that location at each timestep will 
be what gets applied to the nodes that read signals from that node. So 
if you want the input to be applied only on the first timestep then set 
the input nodes to 0 after the first activation.

>
> A side question is that if I save a population in SharpNEAT as an XML file, is some information lost? Whenever I reload a population from file, it's not as fit as when it left off.
>   

There are a couple of possibilities here.

1) When you save and reload a population a lot some state information is 
lost such as the current value of the speciation threshold and which 
genomes are in which species. Therefore the population is re-speciated 
when you start a new run, potentially in a detrimental way if the 
speciation threshold is way off what it should be, and some of the good 
genomes may get culled from the population. E.g if the threshold is too 
high then all genomes might get put into one species, the non-elite 
genomes are culled from this species and replaced with new (generally 
low fitness) offspring. This results in a lower overall population 
fitness than if you had re-speciated into several species, each with 
their own elite (I think!). WEll anyway it won;t be exactly the same result.

2) Some precision may be lost in the (de)serialization of the floating 
point numbers that make up a genome. This is a problem that has been 
fixed in the past but I wouldn't be surprised if it popped up again, 
e.g. if you're running on .Net 2.0.

Hope that helps some,

Colin.
